posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17467312
no. roughout is done to make the boot more resistant to scuffs and abrasion. The fibers on the outside will simply brush back into position.
The downside is that it's harder to get oil out, and because it's the soft fibers out, it's easier for something pointy to begin puncturing the boot, whereas the smooth-out boots, that same pointy bit might just slide off and leave a nasty scratch.

There is no perfect boot, but I love roughout anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17467313
2mm is perfectly thick. Those look like 100 USD boots anyway, so they'll only last you a year of hard wear, or maybe 3-4 of regular wear.
The point of cheap boots is that, if they fail, you can buy another. As long as they don't fail you while you're out in the boonies or up on a mountain it's fiiine.

Toes aren't supposed to touch in boots. The hard leather at the front will mash them up when walking down inclines. Lace-to-toe exists for this reason: lets you get the right tightness across the instep to prevent you slipping all the way forward inside the boot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's something you don't see often. These boots were made between 1988 and 1993 by a now defunct American shoe making company called Stuart McGuire. Found this pair on eBay, all I've done to them is clean, condition and polish.
To be blunt, Stuart McGuire was (for the time) a very middle of the road shoe company, absolutely nothing special. That's what makes these boots surprising, they are pretty much equal in quality to modern offerings from much higher level/established bootmakers.

The leather is thick but supple, feels great on my feet. I'm shocked at how comfortable these boots are on, there's no problem spots. Arch support is superb, the last is a little wide but that works for me. I'm between a 12D and 12E on Brannock, these are a 12D and I can last them nice and tight without feeling like they are too narrow. Length wise is perfect, and the height is good so I can wiggle my toes a little but not feel loose. Heel is fantastic, no slipping. Soles are vibram, some of the stitching is frayed but otherwise the sole is in great shape, with how infrequently I'll wear this it will be years before I'll have to take them to a cobbler. I do need to replace the laces, these are the original and they're a little dingy.

The only downside to these boots are the number of eyelets. 10 eyelets, no speed hooks. I've never seen this system before, I have to thread the lace through these short brass tubes. It doesn't take too long and it feels very supportive once it's laced up.
I'm not a boot expert by any means. I've got Allen Edmonds, Chippewa 1939,Grant Stone, Red Wing, Thorogood, Dan Post, a couple of pair of vintage Florsheim as well. If this boot was handed to me in brand new condition today I'd have zero issue paying current Red Wing prices for it. Really happy I stumbled across it.
Here's some more pics of the boots

https://imgur.com/a/y8pScKr

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17468550
My frame of reference is in canadabucks so bear that in mind.
>Cheap
Arab knockoffs, off-brands and department store shelf goods. Usually from $20-$60. Some deceptively good value in some duplicates if you look around, but be careful not to get scammed.
>Reasonable
Designer house (Dior, Dolce and Gabbana, Versace, Hugo Boss etc.) Eau de Toilettes mostly. Usually around $100 to $140 behind the counter in department stores or at Sephora or your local equivalent, but available much cheaper from reputable online discounters. Always buy from discounters, check the OP. Generally worth the money, will almost always have better performance than their knockoff equivalents.
>Expensive
Niche and upper-rung houses like Creed, Xerjoff, Tom Ford etc. Expect to pay <$300 for a decent sized bottle, or ~$150 for a smaller 30-50ml Eau de Parfum. Usually worth it, but only for something that you've been able to spend some time with in person. Still usually available from discounters.

Entirely based on the person. I consider stuff above 2€/mL basically overpriced (calculated for a 100 mL bottle, usually). There's so much good stuff below that. I try to buy designers at around 0.50€/mL (or less), because they are often on sale for that price. I'll spend up to 1€/mL for the higher quality designers and anything between 1€ and 2€/mL for niche. There are also some fragrances which are within that price range and which I consider interesting, but not interesting enough to buy. I currently have this problem with B683, which smells really good to me, but not 190€/100mL good. For that, it is a tiny bit lacking.
Prices like Roja and Creed ask for are entirely bullshit to me and they won't get my money, simple as. I can find stuff I like better for less money.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17469649
Opium pour homme

it's getting hard to find and price has gone up but it's so worth it still even for $80. Not officially discontinued I guess just not in high circulation.
It's zesty and juicy opening with black current and star anise and dries down to the best vanilla any fragrance has. On the way it gets a kind of bubblegummy smell in the background as the vanilla starts to take over. It's the one scent that gives me a little endorphin rush when I first try it after going a while without it.

Only downside is longevity. It lasts about 3 hours on me before becoming unnoticeable but projection is good for most of that time. But pretty much everything is short lived on my skin.

posts.com: I'll be in a sports complex for most of February and March, in Arizona, mostly outside in the sun. what frag should I wear? Not looking to stand out, just something clean

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17470086
On the same trip my man, been wondering about vintage CW for almost a decade but only recently have i ventured in the world of fragrances because my last teenage frag ended (Boss Element) and i have no signature again, CW being my first and most enduring scent through childhood and teenage years.
I have tested GIT in expensive, perhaps ill-stored decanters and it smells nice but too grassy and no oakmoss/dampness scent, Tres Nuit will be my first buy since i started learning about frags (December last year) and that Floris JF i read yesterday that it's expensive, no good performance and shipping costs a lot but seems to be a fruitier GIT.
Other than that i read about Aventure Knight from Haramain but they say it's too oriental and strong for its own good, Chez Bond no. 9 seems to be similar to CW in the aperture but the drydown is supposedly creamier/floral rather than woody.

>but it is much more floral
How so? iris, violet?
Also about Aspen because it is the same bottle and made by Coty i always discarded it but your words have interested me, what i truly miss from CW is not the high-quality non-stringent calone but the greeness/oakmoss aspect of its base note, which is totally absent in Coty CW.
>It's unfortuneatly like a pixelated photo.
For me it's almost a different frag, it's very sharp in the aperture and dries down to a salty old lemon while vintage opened with pleasant soft calone and lemon with a strong hint of greeness and dried down to the smell of humid cedar with a bit of tobacco. Fresh vintage CW was something else, much more complex than today and it's a shame few newcomers know exactly why it was so rampantly popular to the point of surpassing Drakkar Noir.

>>17470876
It's easier to describe a fragrance by vibe than by actual notes. Whenever I pass by a juniper tree, I am reminded that the smell of "juniper" in fragrances rarely matches real juniper. Most lavender doesn't smell like lavender yet every fougere claims to have it (Invasion Barbare is the only stuff that smells like actual lavender mixed with lavender oil to me). It's hard to describe chemicals which by now might even be entirely "made up" with no natural counterpart. My SOTD is Eau des Baux - a spicy opening, but is it cardamom and pink pepper? Not really. It's spicy and a bit peppery, for sure, but that's it. Is the drydown cypress and incense? Not really. Vanilla and tonka bean? There's certainly vanilla, but tonka bean feels like one of those "random" notes like "amber" by now, even though it technically means coumarin. I could say it smells like Christmas, but so does Egoiste or SWY Absolutely, just in a different way. It's just an easy way to describe something, except for maybe civet since that's an actual note.

>>17469373
>Sport coats

If you've never gotten into them before, either have a friend measure you or paid a tailor 20 bucks to do it. I'd go to the tailor because you're going to probably need to build a relationship with one eventually

Here are the measurements you need in descending importance:

1 Shoulders
2 Chest
3 Waist
4 Sleeves

Shoulders will fuck your fit up and can not be adjusted. Remind yourself of this dozens of times. If your shoulders are 18", you can wear sport coats that are 18-19". Anything too small won't fit, and anything too large will look awful and you can't really cheat around it by adding bulky layers either.

Chest and waist are way easier to work with, if it's a couple inches big they can be taken in. I am cheap and want to avoid the tailor because I am also lazy so I am for sport coats that have a few inches drop between chest and west to emphasize my torso and make me look less like a sack of potatoes. If my chest is 45, I want my waist on the coat to be 41-42. Nothing massive because I'm not in great shape.
Note that this isn't my actual waist, that's a 36.

Sleeves are normally easy to deal with. If they are too long, hem them. If they are a little short don't panic, there's normally an inch built in for adjustment.

Once you have those measurements it's just a matter of patience on eBay. Search for your chest, and then match your measurements from the tailor with the measurements provided by the seller.

>>17469555
>Haha, i like them billowy like that. Its just a full cut, not the wrong size - the neck, armholes, and cuffs fit well.

For the record, that can still be the wrong size. I'm the guy giving sport coat sizing advice, didn't want to go into too much at once and make things more complicated than needed but here's so more info:

My chest is 42", but my neck is 16.5" and it's snug at 16.5. My sleeve length is 36. So if I blindly buy a 16.5x36 dress shirt, the body often billows because my powerful lizard like neck is meant to be with a size 46 to 48 shirt for the chest measurement.

I'm 6'3 and about 215, but even when I was 150 and so much hotter my neck size was still the same. What to do?

1: Buy shirts from retailers like Charles Tyrwhitt that let you choose "cuts". I get a 16.5x36 extra slim. That way my neck isn't choked, but the torso is thinner and so are the sleeves

2: Buy a shirt that fits torso and use collar extenders. It's basically an invisible button with an elastic loop that you attach to your collar button, increases the collar size by an inch. If you're wearing a tie, it's invisible. If you're not wearing a tie, don't button the top button, and then you're fine.

3: Made to measure shirts. This is where I'm gravitating towards now that I get the process and know where to go. This way the shirt will be designed to fit you perfectly

>>17434337
This >>17434391 is the advice you need. Just keep in mind what type of fit you're looking for. If you're considering getting one of their slim or slim tapered fits, be honest about whether this could be a little too tight. I've owned a pair of their slim tapered jeans and wore them for a few months only to find out that I absolutely hate the fit and prefer their straight tapered fit infinitely more since it gives me workable crotch mobility and doesn't have the feminine appearance of having the thighs too tight and the calve region being loose. If you order a pair only to find out you should have gone just one size up in waist, Iron Heart's customer service is top notch. If you're american, you could order a pair from Self Edge, Iron Shop Provisions, or Division Road and not have to deal with the longer shipping times from shipping overseas to Iron Heart's HQ in the UK.

>>17460461
I had a pair of Momotaro jeans and they were amazing. They shrank in the wash and i gained weight so i had to get rid of them which sucked
You could buy any one of those brands and be satisfied. They're all on an extremely high level of quality. Iron Heart specifically does super heavy denim. That's their niche, but that doesn't mean the rest aren't every bit as good
Samurai is amazing and will probably be my next pair. Pure Blue Japan is also really interesting. Honestly just look at the brands and find what you think you'll like and go for it. You can't go wrong

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17469849
Here's what I found prolongs the life of my jeans.
-wash once every 6 months or per year. I have a bunch of them and rotate a lot. But if yours get really dirty you might want to wash mote often.
-Use non-abrassive detergent. For this purpose I use my country's equivalent of tide pods. Powder detergent wears my clothes, gel type does not.
-wash inside out, cold cycle, about 30 degress celsius. On my washing machine I use either a delicate or wool cycle.
-do not tumble dry. Puy them on a line as straight as posdible and let them air dry still inside out until their dry but the fabric still has a sort of moisture to it. Not wet, but doesn't have to feel sandy dry to the touch.
After trying several methods this is the one that prolongs the life of my jeans and the original color for longer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17456900
First of all, you have curly hair. Secondly, only using shampoo will keep stripping all of the hydrating oils, which is what is making it so frizzy.

Use shampoo and then conditioner, only wash your hair every second night, and use a conditioning mask for 10-30min once a week. Don't rush your hair once it's dry - just run your fingers through while the conditioner is in it to separate tangles. You'll get some nice, smooth waves and curls.
You can use a leave-in oil product too if you want to go the extra mile. I out maybe a tablespoon of oil in my hair while it's soaking wet out of the shower, then leave to air dry (but it's much longer than yours, you'll figure out the perfect amount.)

posts.name: Anonymous

Fasting + strength training is ideal for weight loss. Muscle gain raises your baseline energy consumption so you can keep fat off even after you stop fasting, and no exercise causes muscle atrophy (which means no hungry muscles to consume food right away). Pushups and squats with no weights are enough for the average person. Just start with 10 of each every weekday and work up your way from there.

>>17465424
>https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
By June? Fill in numbers and see what results you get. If you're really just fat and are not physically active you'll need to cut a lot lower to look thin. You could lose 10kg by June with diet alone but then you'd need to lose even more. I suggest swimming or rowing for an hour a day while eating more protein at 500 cals under TDEE. Some say lifting is better and apparently having more muscle does raise TDEE but if you're just fat and sedentary, any consistent exercise will build some muscle. Swimming and rowing are great forms of cardio because they burn the most calories & both work almost every muscle in your body. Cardio also makes sex much better. Five months should be enough time assuming you're consistent with your intake and exercise.

>>17455864
Yeah, it's a bad faith argument. When you say "milsurp" and ask if it can mix with TIP, you're obviously not asking if trench coats and khaki pants and desert boots are TIP, because they obviously are. You're asking if you can wear flecktarn and spetsnaz boots with a TIP fit and not look ridiculous, and the answer is generally "no." If you're going for the TIP aesthetic but like milsurp, that's fine, but save it for an appropriate situation like going hunting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17455373
I'd say I take a middle ground on this issue. Clothes that would be worn in combat 1970s-onward would clash, because combat gear from then on has been so drastically different from normal clothing. Earlier than that could possibly work, depending on the item. There are a lot of WWII items that can work with TIP clothes while still having more of an obviously military appearance than older heritage items like trench coats. Pic rel is a menswear blogger I like wearing a vintage Marine Corps service jacket with a TIP resort outfit.

>>17461918
For basic dress shirts they are fantastic for the price and punch well above their weight. Don't be a retard, always buy them 3 for 99, the full cost price is a scam and kind of scummy but it traps retards so fuck it.

I've been buying shirts from them for eight years, I still have the original shirts I bought. They hold up well, and being able to pick your collar, sleeve and overall fit means even if you have weird proportions like me (long arms skinny chest) you'll be able to find a shirt you can wear right off the rack. Like any non bespoke shirt they will look better with some minor tailoring but overall I think they're great.

All this philosophical stuff is really boring and, judging by his reply, none of your assumptions were actually correct anyways so its all irrelevant.

The problem with your whole line of thinking is that, at this point, the line of menswear has been completely severed for most guys in America. In the past, people would experiment with the kind of clothing their fathers wore, innovating within what society considered acceptable dress. Now many guys' fathers just wear t-shirts and jeans, and societal standards for everything have eroded into nothing. In that context, many young guys are going to start from scratch, without that kind of lovely effortless menswear wardrobe mindset you describe. So preaching that they should just have that instead of trying to look into particular styles for inspiration is pointless concern trolling. And again, really boring.

>>17461493
if you actually want to make this more TIP then higher rise pants that are less tapered are the first thing. Second would be a button down or crewneck sweater as your tops. Third would be to focus on lower contrast pieces.

On the other hand, you don't really look like you want to be TIP, just work appropriate. I still think higher rise pants are a good idea, to balance out your proportions. I'd also still consider more muted pants and adding a sweater or light jacket (maybe a shirt jacket) as a top layer. Try a white or grey button down and tees without graphics.


>>17463351

>>17463397
I don't think that poster was commenting on the mohair itself. Buying bespoke second hand can be problematic, since its less likely to fit another owner than an OTR garrment. It can still be a good deal though

>>17465052
looks ok, but room for improvement:
-shirt collar would ideally stay inside the sweater. It also looks overly formal for the casualness of the rest of the fit. Try a button down collar in a color or more textured fabric.
-pants cuff is sloppy and doesn't transiftion nicely to the shoes. Try wearing them uncuffed. Also consider less skinny pants if you want to up the formality.
-shoes are pretty casual when the pants are rolled up like that, longer pants would make them fit better overall
-I like the fit of the sweater and the colors on everything go nicely
